persona.name: María del Rosario Ríos Valencia

occupation.title: Informal fisher, small-scale seafood vendor and seasonal tourism food seller
occupation.description: Works informally as a small-scale fisher and vendor. Her work includes going out to sea in a small motorized skiff or joining a group of fishers for in-shore nets at dawn; cleaning and preserving fish; preparing simple cooked dishes (ceviche, fried fish, fish tacos) to sell from a shaded stall or to local palapas when tourists come; and sometimes taking small groups on short, informal boat rides for visitors. Responsibilities: maintenance of the skiff and nets, early-morning fishing or collecting shellfish, negotiating sales to middlemen or at market, food preparation and hygiene, basic price-setting, supervising her teenage helper (often a niece or younger sibling), and keeping an informal tally of daily expenses and earnings. Skills used: knowledge of tides and weather, species identification, fish-cleaning, basic motor maintenance, cooking, bartering, and community networking. Income is irregular and strongly seasonal; often combined with ad-hoc work in hospitality (cleaning rentals, helping at local festivals) when fishing is poor. No formal labor contract, pays no taxes regularly, sometimes receives remittances from a sibling working in the U.S. or an interior city.

persona.residence: Small coastal village near San Andrés Tuxtla, Veracruz, Mexico
persona.education: Completed secundaria (equivalent to middle/high school). Attended a rural telesecundaria and finished preparatoria-equivalent courses informally while helping her family; no tertiary degree. Has practical vocational knowledge learned on the water, in markets, and in community workshops.
long_term_goals: Ensure her two children finish at least secundaria and have alternatives to the precarious fishing life.
Improve the family's concrete-block house (add a proper kitchen, a water tank and roofing) so it resists storms.
Create a steady micro-business selling prepared seafood and local crafts to domestic tourists year-round, not just seasonally.
See her village recognized and celebrated for Afro-Mexican culture—help preserve traditional music, dance and recipes.
Gain secure access to public healthcare services for her family and reduce out-of-pocket expenses.
Save enough to send one child to a technical school (pesca artesanal maintenance or hospitality) within 5–8 years.
Build a small emergency savings fund (target: about $500–$1,000 USD) to avoid relying on informal credit.
Be part of a local cooperative with other fishers and vendors to get better prices and share resources.
Participate in municipal consultations so the community's voice matters in fishing regulations and tourism plans.
Maintain cultural continuity—teach her children traditional drumming rhythms and dances she learned from her mother.

style.general: Warm, direct, outgoing within her community, cautious with strangers. Speaks in a coastal Veracruz Spanish with a musical cadence and occasional African-influenced rhythmic phrasing; uses local colloquialisms and terms of affection like "mi'ja", "mi'jo", "compa". Quick to laugh, often gestures with her hands when telling a story. Dresses practically: colorful cotton blouses, worn jeans or a skirt depending on the day, rubber sandals for work, and a well-used wide-brim straw hat for sun protection. When preparing food she ties a patterned apron; for festivals she wears dresses with bright embroidery and shells. Sings or hums traditional son jarocho or marimba rhythms while working. Speaks politely with elders and uses a sing-song cadence when calling to the water.
style.speech_and_mannerisms: Uses proverbs and short narratives to make points; frequently repeats key words for emphasis; pauses to laugh or clap once when amused; often breaks into short traditional refrains when nervous. Speaks loudly enough to be heard across a market stall but softens voice when addressing children or elders. When stressed, chews on a fingernail or rubs the back of her neck. Habitually greets neighbors with a short kiss on the cheek and asks about family members by name.
style.formality: Casual in everyday interactions, respectful and formal in church settings and when dealing with municipal authorities. When trying to get something from officials, she adopts a more organized tone and brings receipts or a list.
style.technology_style: Light user: owns an inexpensive Android smartphone. Uses WhatsApp for family chats and to coordinate sales; rarely uses Facebook but checks community pages when neighbors share important information. Charges her phone at a neighbor's house if there is no solar charger. Prefers in-person negotiations over digital contracts and uses cash for most transactions.

traits: Resilient: recovers from setbacks quickly and looks for practical solutions.
Protective: places family and close friends first, will defend them vocally.
Sociable: enjoys gossiping and storytelling; well-known in the plaza.
Proud: strong sense of Afro-Mexican identity and local traditions.
Pragmatic: prioritizes immediate needs and practical outcomes over abstract plans.
Generous: shares fish and food with neighbors, even when money is tight.
Skeptical of outsiders: cautious about offers that sound too good to be true.
Faithful: faith informs many decisions; participates in church and patron-saint events.
Anxious about money: worries frequently about unpredictable income and children's future.
Playful: good-natured teasing is her common form of affection.
Adaptable: shifts roles between fisher, cook, vendor, mother, and community organizer as needed.
Stubborn: once decided, she pushes for her course and resists quick changes.
Observant: notices small shifts in weather, social dynamics, and price changes.
Community-oriented: invests time in communal events and mutual aid networks.
Sentimental: keeps mementos from festivals and photos of departed relatives.

big_five.openness: Medium. Appreciates tradition and storytelling but is open to small practical innovations (a better engine, a new recipe).
big_five.conscientiousness: Medium-High. Reliable in daily duties, careful with family schedules and food preparation, keeps informal records of finances.
big_five.extraversion: High. Energized by markets, church, and festivals; enjoys conversation and singing with others.
big_five.agreeableness: High. Helpful, trusting with neighbors, though can be firm when protecting family interests.
big_five.neuroticism: Medium. Worries about finances and weather; can be emotionally reactive under stress but usually recovers quickly.

interests: Traditional Afro-Mexican music (son jarocho, marimba, local drumming patterns).
Dancing at community festivals and church posadas.
Cooking family ceviche recipes and experimenting with citrus and coconut flavors.
Collecting shells and simple beaded jewelry-making.
Gardening small plots of plantains, peppers, and herbs.
Following local news about fishing restrictions or municipal payments.
Visiting the local mercado to compare prices and talk with vendors.
Attending Sunday mass and participating in religious processions.
Listening to older neighbors' stories about migration and the sea.
Teaching her children local songs and rhythms.
Watching occasional television novelas when electricity allows.
Listening to radio programs about weather and fishing reports.
Buying small, practical gifts for Godchildren during festivals.
Participating in mutual-help (fondo) arrangements with neighbors.
Learning short English phrases from returning migrants to greet tourists.
Collecting traditional recipes written in an old notebook passed down from her mother.
Observing the tides and tracking seasonal species.
Supporting local artisans by buying ribbons and beads for dresses.
Keeping an eye on remittances arrival dates and who's traveling through the bus station.
Attending informal community meetings about land use and coastal conservation.
Favors local markets over big city stores.
Enjoys bright colors—turquoise, coral, and yellow—in clothing and home textiles.
Prefers hands-on, communal learning rather than formal classes.
Likes to bargain but avoids aggressive haggling that would offend sellers she knows.
Enjoys storytelling with spices of humor and exaggeration, often in short episodes.
likes: Freshly caught fish prepared simply with lime and chile.
Coconut water straight from the nut on hot afternoons.
The sound of batucada-style drumming and communal singing.
Church bazaar foods during patron-saint festivals.
Handmade embroidered blouses and colorful aprons.
Sitting at the market early to see who has new arrivals.
The smell of frying fish in the morning.
Neighbors dropping by unannounced with small gifts.
Children playing traditional games in the plaza.
Small, steady improvements to the house: a new tile, a repaired door.
Having enough cash to pay the electricity and to buy school supplies.
Simple household appliances that save time: an efficient stove or cooler box.
Stories of ancestors and lessons passed down orally.
A trustworthy middleman who pays a fair price for fish.
Being addressed with respect by younger neighbors.
When a tourist genuinely appreciates local food and culture (rather than taking pictures without buying anything).
Singing while working; rhythm helps the day pass.
A good, dependable neighbor who watches the children during emergencies.
Free health campaigns in the community that bring clinics to the village.
Shared meals after a successful fishing trip.
Receiving remittances at predictable times.
A steady, trustworthy engine for her skiff.
Neighbors participating in church and community events.
Receiving praise for her cooking from regular customers.
Seasonal mangos and plantains from a neighbor's tree.
dislikes: Promises from politicians that never materialize.
Middlemen who cheat or underpay fishers.
Big commercial tourist operators who bring pollution and undercut local sellers.
Being told by outsiders that traditions are 'backward.'
Severe storms that destroy nets and roofs.
People who don't return borrowed tools or money.
Long waits at municipal offices and endless paperwork.
Health clinics that open infrequently or lack medicines.
When electricity fails during a busy night selling to tourists.
Rude tourists who touch things without asking.
High-interest informal loans that trap families in debt.
Being patronized by NGOs that don't include community voices.
Children leaving school early without a plan.
Intrusive researchers who ask questions but don't share results.
Prejudice or subtle exclusion because of her Afro-Mexican appearance.
When younger people devalue traditional music and dance.
Large trawlers that make small-scale fishing unprofitable.
Fake remedies sold door-to-door for common illnesses.
Plastic pollution washing into the shoreline.
Exorbitant prices for basic building materials.

beliefs: The government should guarantee basic healthcare for everyone; public clinics must be accessible and stocked.
Education is the best route for children to have more choices than hard manual labor.
Small fishers and vendors deserve fair prices and protection from industrial fleets.
Morena's emphasis on social programs benefits people like her more than prior administrations.
Remittances from relatives abroad are essential but not a long-term solution to structural poverty.
Catholic faith and community rituals provide social cohesion and moral guidance.
Afro-Mexican culture should be taught in local schools and preserved publicly.
Women in the community should be able to run businesses and make decisions—gender roles can be flexible when needed.
Traditional medicine and home remedies are valuable but clinics are necessary for serious conditions.
Local cooperatives can improve bargaining power and reduce exploitation by intermediaries.
Corruption is a major obstacle to village development—money promised at town hall often disappears.
Young people are pressured by migration narratives; sending them away is both opportunity and loss.
Tourism can help economically if it respects local customs and hires locals.
Climate change is visible in changing fish patterns and stronger storms; policies must address it.
It's important to teach children to respect elders and keep family ties strong.
Community festivals and patron-saint days are essential for identity and mental health.
Property titles and secure land tenure would help families access credit and invest.
Informal lending systems are necessary but risky when crises hit.
Public investment in roads, waste collection, and potable water would dramatically improve life.
She prefers local solutions made by residents over external 'development' projects imposed from above.
The sea is both livelihood and risk: one must respect it and prepare for its dangers.
Children should learn trades (boat repair, hospitality, cooking) as practical alternatives to leaving home.
Government pensions for elderly and disabled relatives would reduce multigenerational strain.
Security is important; petty theft and drug-related problems in nearby towns worry her.
She distrusts promises from political newcomers until she sees concrete results.
Small investments in cold storage would reduce spoilage and increase income.
Conserving mangroves and reefs is important for long-term fish stocks and storm protection.
Solidarity among neighbors is the best immediate safety net; communal savings and shared labor work.
Her identity as Afro-Mexican is a source of pride and a justification to demand respect and anti-discrimination measures.
Young women should have access to contraception and sexual education to make safer choices.
Public transport improvements would make secondary schooling and medical visits more viable.
She believes in practical, visible change (a repaired road, a clinic day) rather than abstract promises.
Religious leaders can help mediate disputes, but community councils must have real voice in municipal decisions.
Access to microcredit with reasonable terms could help start a proper food stall or buy a reliable motor.
Foods and rituals tied to Afro-Mexican heritage are medicine for the soul and must be included in cultural festivals.
Teaching children music and dance builds self-esteem and community continuity.
She believes small, incremental savings matter more than grand plans that never happen.
Local youth programs (sports, music) can reduce risky behavior and build future leaders.
Women's informal networks are powerful but need recognition and occasional funding.
It's important to maintain bilingual awareness—Spanish for official matters, local terms and rhythms in home life.
skills: Skilled at identifying local fish and shellfish species by sight and seasonality.
Experienced in setting and mending gillnets and handlines; basic ropework.
Boat handling in shallow inshore waters; maintaining a small outboard motor (change oil, clean carburetor).
Fish cleaning, filleting, and basic preservation (ice/solar coolers, salting in small batches).
Ceviche and fried fish preparation with know-how on marination times and local citrus blends.
Negotiation and bartering skills developed in markets and with middlemen.
Basic bookkeeping: keeps cash tallies in a small ledger or notebook; tracks who owes what.
Community organizing: coordinates shifts for festival preparations and shared labor on neighbor projects.
Childcare and household management while running a micro-business.
Simple sewing and mending of nets and clothing; basic embroidery learned from relatives.
Ability to teach traditional songs and rhythms to children and small groups.
Basic first-aid knowledge: treating cuts, heat-stroke prevention, saltwater rinses for minor wounds.
Practical problem-solving: improvising boat repairs and fixing makeshift shade for stalls.
Understanding of local bylaws and fishing seasons through experience and conversations with other fishers.
Oral storytelling and persuasive description to market dishes to tourists.

general: Greets everyone in the plaza by name in the morning and asks after their children.
Starts work before sunrise; returns home midday for a brief rest or to check children.
Sings or hums while cleaning fish and preparing orders.
Regularly shares a portion of a good catch with elderly neighbors.
Keeps a small notebook with daily earnings, debts and reminders pinned under a magnet in the kitchen.
Checks the weather radio or neighbors' reports before planning a fishing trip.
When a municipal truck brings a clinic, she line-ups early to get medicines for family.
Occasionally borrows small sums from a rotating fund when expenses spike.
Tactfully refuses aggressive tourist offers but tries to upsell food to friendly visitors.
Uses humor and teasing to defuse conflicts and maintain social harmony.
Offers to teach visiting children a simple drumming beat during festivals.
Attends church regularly but prioritizes community welfare over ritual when in conflict.

morning: Wakes at 4:15–4:45 AM depending on tide and month.
Makes coffee in a small pot, quickly feeds the youngest child, packs ice and containers.
Head out to sea in the skiff or joins a neighbor crew, checks nets and lines.
Returns around 8:30–10:00 AM with the morning catch, cleans fish at the beach or at home.
Prepares the day's food batch and sets up the stall before the mercado opens.
workday: Sells fish and prepared dishes until noon or early afternoon; often takes orders for evening meals.
Runs errands: buys fuel, ice, or small groceries; sometimes visits the municipal office or health brigade.
If tourism present, coordinates with palapa owners or small coastal hostels for supply.
Teaches children simple tasks: wrapping food, rinsing vegetables, adding citrus to ceviche.
evening: Shares dinner with family; evening is for storytelling and listening to radio.
Helps children with homework when electricity allows, and practices songs or dance steps on festival nights.
Repairs nets or mends clothing by lamplight; counts the day's earnings and plans for the next day.
Prays briefly before bed; sleeps early to rest for the next dawn.
weekend: Attends communal cleaning or church events, prepares larger batches of food for fiestas.
Visits extended family in neighboring villages or receives visitors who bring supplies.
Participates in music rehearsals or practices dances for upcoming celebrations.
May travel to the nearest town for bulk purchases or to process paperwork.

health.general: Moderate health typical of a physically active rural worker. Stamina from daily physical labor but with cumulative wear.
chronic_conditions: Intermittent lower back pain and shoulder strain from hauling nets and lifting ice boxes.
Mild, untreated dental disease (missing molars and periodic toothaches) due to limited access to affordable dentistry.
acute_issues: Had a cut from a net three years ago that required a clinic visit; healed but left a small scar on her forearm.
Seasonal minor gastrointestinal upset occasionally after eating street food; manages with home remedies and if severe visits clinic during municipal health brigades.
mental_health: Occasional anxiety related to finances and children's schooling; can feel sleepless the few nights before storm season or when remittances are late.
Generally emotionally resilient, supported by strong social ties and faith practices.
health.reproductive_health: Has had multiple pregnancies with normal vaginal deliveries; last pregnancy and child spacing managed through community health advice. Uses modern contraception intermittently depending on access.
health.access_to_care: Prefers the public health clinic when it is functioning; sometimes travels to the municipal hospital for more serious concerns. Supports government healthcare expansion because it would reduce out-of-pocket spending.
health.nutrition: Diet heavy on fish, rice, plantain and seasonal fruits; occasional lack of variety during lean months can cause fatigue. Drinks coffee regularly and plain water; avoids sugary drinks due to expense.
health.preventive_behaviors: Participates in vaccination campaigns for children and attends occasional health talks at the church or school when available.

relationships.name: Pedro Ríos (husband/partner)
relationships.description: Co-owner of the skiff; a practical, taciturn man who alternates fishing and temporary construction work inland. They are married/long-term cohabitants. Pedro handles most of the motor maintenance, while María manages sales and cooking. They make financial decisions together but arguments arise when money is scarce.

relationships.name: Luisa (daughter, 14)
relationships.description: Studious and musical; helps at the stall on weekends and is learning drumming. María worries about her finishing school but is proud of her responsibility.

relationships.name: Javier (son, 10)
relationships.description: Energetic, helps bait hooks and fetch ice. Loves the water and is learning to swim in shallow coves under supervision.

relationships.name: Doña Carmen (mother, 64)
relationships.description: Lives nearby. She taught María traditional recipes and songs. Slightly frail but central to family life; respected matriarch and godmother to many in the village.

relationships.name: Two brothers (one works seasonally in Oaxaca, the other in Veracruz city)
relationships.description: Occasional remitters who bring small cash infusions during lean periods; keep regular contact via phone.

relationships.name: Neighbors and co-vendors
relationships.description: A rotating network of 8–10 families who coordinate stall shifts, share news about weather, and pool labor for festival preparations; often exchange goods and favors.

relationships.name: Local parish priest
relationships.description: Respected figure who organizes patron-saint festivals and coordinates charity; María is an active participant and sometimes volunteers to prepare communal meals.

relationships.name: Young apprentice (niece, 17)
relationships.description: Helps some afternoons learning net mending and basic sales; occasionally asks María about migrating to the city for work—a topic María worries about.

relationships.name: A trusted middleman/buyer in the municipal market
relationships.description: Buys fish at slightly better prices when María's catch is good; their relationship is based on years of reliable transactions and mutual respect.

relationships.name: Women’s rotating savings group (fondo)
relationships.description: Informal group of 10 women who save and lend small amounts to each other monthly; María both borrows and contributes when possible.

other_facts: Born in the same village where she lives; family has lived on that coast for at least three generations.
Her maternal grandmother was a prominent singer in local festivals and taught María call-and-response songs.
Has a small, cherished notebook with hand-written recipes and a few faded photographs of past festivals.
Once nearly lost the skiff during a sudden storm five years ago; neighbors organized a rescue and the event deepened communal ties.
Keeps a painted wooden rosary given by her godmother during her first communion.
Has a tradition of making a special fish stew every time a child passes an exam.
Participated in a municipal cooperative meeting once and felt frustrated by technical language and the lack of translation into plain Spanish.
Has an old, hand-me-down radio that she uses to follow local weather bulletins and listen to radio novelas.
Learnt basic embroidery patterns from her aunt and sells a few embroidered napkins to tourists occasionally.
Once traveled by bus to the state capital with her husband to buy an engine part; the trip took the whole day and felt like an adventure.
Keeps a secret stash of about $20–$30 USD hidden in a tin for emergencies.
Was a bridesmaid in three community weddings and took pride in homemade dresses and shared dances.
Has a tradition of baking a cassava cake for the patron-saint procession.
Her eldest cousin migrated to the U.S. eight years ago and sends money sporadically; that cousin taught her a few English phrases over WhatsApp.
Knows the name of almost every regular customer by order preference ("el que siempre pide doble limón").
When her children were small she saved a small sewn coin pouch for each child for school fees.
Her family's house has one room with a painted mural of a seascape her brother made—she plans to protect it during storms.
Was once approached by a tourist NGO that wanted to 'document Afro-Mexican traditions' but the project never returned; she is wary of researchers now.
Hosted a small pilgrimage group once and made a profit by preparing meals; found the experience positive when people were respectful.
Has a recurring dream about a large net full of bright fish—a symbol she shares as a blessing for the family.
Uses a rhythm with a conch-shell call to gather children during beach games.
Knows safe and riskier inlets for netting at different moon phases.
Has an old ledger where she keeps birthdates and saints' days for extended family so she can prepare food and visits accordingly.
All her children were baptized in the same parish and have godparents within the village network.
Once organized a small clean-up of a particularly polluted shoreline patch and convinced three other families to join.
She was taught a practical trick for preserving fish in the dry season using extra salt and an improvised shade structure.
Her favorite festival memory: dancing until dawn with a borrowed dress after her wedding when the whole village celebrated.
A piece of driftwood from her childhood sits by the house door and is used as an informal knife holder.
She keeps receipts and small municipal notices pinned to the kitchen wall in case officials ask for copies.
Her daughter Luisa won a small prize in a school singing contest singing an old call-and-response; María was very proud and framed the flyer.
Has a small collection of shells used as informal currency in some barters and as tokens for children.
Learned to drive the skiff herself during a neighbor's illness when no one else was available.
Once lent her entire day's earnings to a neighbor for a medical emergency and the favor was repaid months later with fish and labor.
Has kept a small altar during times of drought where neighbors leave offerings for good catch.
Has a neighbor who is a retired teacher who helps her children with schoolwork in exchange for cooked meals.
She sometimes records short voice messages to relatives who live in interior cities because writing is slower for them.
Her household electricity is on a prepaid meter; topping it up is a weekly financial calculation.
Has participated twice in municipal vaccination campaigns, bringing two children each time to the clinic truck parked in the plaza.
Owns one small crate of borrowed tools that she shares with neighbors—hammers, a patch kit, spare rope.
Her favorite meal to serve to honored guests is fried fish with coconut rice and fried plantain.
When a researcher returned months later with copies of photos and a small reimbursement, trust in outsiders increased; that memory shapes how she evaluates new projects.
She learned basic arithmetic from a community adult education class a few years ago and uses it to calculate change and earnings.
Has a superstition that whistling at night near the shore invites storm winds; she avoids it during certain months.
Was part of a cultural exchange once with a nearby town where children learned a hybrid song that is now part of the local repertoire.
Her house has two small banners from past patron-saint celebrations; she vows to add one more the next time funds allow.
